awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Bio-Inspired Electrochemical Sensing of Small Molecules using Antibodies
awd_abstract_narration:
PI: Goluch, Edgar D. 
Proposal Number: 1740961 

A new approach for measuring small biological molecules such as toxins found in surface water is proposed.  The approach, if successful, can provide a basis for compact devices that are portable for measuring harmful molecules. 

There is a scarcity of sensors for detection of small biological molecules. The current approach - enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) - generally cannot be used for sensing small biomolecules due to limited binding sites on the antigen. An alternative approach is needed. Antibodies that have antigens bound to them are recognized in mammalian systems by C1q protein. It is generally accepted that all antibodies undergo a conformational change when they bind to an antigen. The change is recognized by the protein, C1q, which attaches to the conserved, Fc, region of the antibody.  In the proposed work, C1q recognition event will be used to examine feasibility of detecting small bioanalytes in aqueous samples.   The binding measurements and characterization will be performed using commercially available instrument systems. In the second aim, C1q protein will be modified with a redox-active molecule for measuring using voltammetry-based electrochemical sensor, as it is a simple, robust, and mature technology.  If the project is successful, it is expected to be broadly applicable to many sensing application with the potential to develop a low-cost, portable electrochemical sensing platform. The project will provide undergraduate and graduate students with multidisciplinary research experiences that will foster collaboration between engineers and biologists, preparing them for future workplace environments.

por.por_cntn:
Overview

There is a scarcity of simple, rapid sensors for detection of small molecules. The most popular approach for detecting biological molecules, the enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA), generally cannot be used for sensing molecules that have low molecular weights, such as environmental contaminants or hormones. ELISA traditionally requires the formation of a sandwich, first attaching the target molecule (antigen) to an antibody that is immobilized on a surface followed by identification of the binding event with a second antibody that attaches to a different location (epitope) on the antigen. While many small biomolecules cause an antibiotic response, meaning that antibodies can be developed that bind to them, the physical size of these molecules is too small to have two different antibodies attach to them. To work around this limitation, competition assays can be utilized where a synthetic molecule is created that competes against the antigen for attachment to the immobilized antibodies. Detection of the antigen then depends on measuring the change in the amount of synthetic molecules that bind to the antibodies. This approach requires development of a new synthetic molecule for each antigen of interest.

A more sophisticated approach to avoid using two antibodies is to instead employ label-free techniques that detect the binding of an antigen onto antibodies immobilized on the sensor surface. However, low-molecular-weight molecules are often also too small to be detected by label-free techniques, such as Surface Plasmon Resonance (SPR) or Quartz Crystal Microbalance (QCM) sensors. Other label-free techniques, such as mass spectrometry, require extensive sample processing and large equipment. Therefore, there is a need to develop techniques that are designed for sensing this class of molecules. This project investigated a new sensing mechanism that was inspired by the sensing strategy that mammals use to detect foreign objects inside their bodies. It was found that the natural sensing mechanism was too complex to integrate into a laboratory testing setup. However, several new insights were gained during the project into how the natural mechanism can be potentially simplified so that the concept could can be utilized in an in vitro testing platform in the future.

Intellectual Merit

This EAGER project evaluated the use of C1q protein as a universal marker in a new sensing platform for the detection of antibodies that have bound to their target. The fundamental premise for this project is based on the function that C1q plays in mammals. In the body, C1q selectively binds to antibodies that have an antigen bound to them. It was found that C1q was too sticky to work in an in vitro sensing platform. In other words, C1q bound non-specifically to synthetic surfaces. Several coatings were tested to reduce the non-specific adsorption of C1q, but none significantly prevented attachment of the protein onto the sensor surface. More complex strategies for minimizing C1q non-specific adsorption were identified, however additional research is necessary to test the new ideas.

The second aim of this project evaluated the use of voltammetry-based measurements to detect target antigens. The C1q was to be modified with an electro-active molecule to allow for its detection upon binding with antigen-antibody complexes. While detection using C1q could not be performed, the mechanism for detecting its binding with complexes was verified. In the process, a new method for improving the sensitivity of the voltammetric sensor was developed and validated.

Broader Impacts

Two graduate and two undergraduate students were trained to perform biosensor research and perform electrochemical measurements. A patent disclosure and subsequent application have been filed based on the technology developed during this project. Multiple conference presentations were given, and two peer-reviewed journal papers have been published to help disseminate the findings throughout the scientific community.
